abstract.text: Handles an error that occurs during an attempt to read, save, or revert a document.

inlineContent.text: An object encapsulating information about an error encountered in an attempt to open, save, or revert a document. The error domain is
. The error code is one of the
constants declared in
If
, no attempt is (or should be) made to present a modal view to the user. This value can be
in cases such as when a save operation fails while the application is being suspended. If this parameter is
, UIKit or your override may present error information to the user in a modal view and (optionally) allow the user to resolve the error.
Typical
subclasses don’t need to call or override this method. Instead, they can observe the
notification to be notified of changes in document state. In their notification handler, they can check the value of the
property and proceed accordingly. See
for a discussion of this.
If you’re using managed documents (instances of the
subclass), you must subclass this method and, if desired, the
method. Subclassing allows your app to observe errors in saving or validation. The
notification doesn’t contain a
dictionary and so doesn’t convey specific error information.
If you directly call any of the advanced reading and writing methods that have an error-object parameter (for example,
) and that call returns an
object by indirection, you should call this method (
), passing in the error object.
This method is called by the default implementations of
and
when
encounters a reading or writing error, respectively.
If you override this method and don’t invoke the superclass implementation (
), you’re responsible for the following:
Calling
when you’re finished handling the error — for example, when the application doesn’t require any additional user feedback about the error.
Implementing
to conclude error handling immediately. If
is
, you should immediately handle the error and call
within the context of the

abstract.text: Cocoa errors
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A false value.
A true value.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An abstract base class for managing discrete portions of your app’s data.
The current state of the document.
Tells UIKit that you finished handling the error.
Handles an error that occurs during an attempt to read, save, or revert a document.
Opens a document asynchronously.
Saves document data to the specified location in the application sandbox.
A notification the document object posts when there’s a change in the state of the document.
Indicates when it’s no longer safe to proceed without immediately handling the error.
Ensures that document data is written safely to a specified location in the application sandbox.
A managed document object that integrates with Core Data.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
